I have used it mostly when I found a coursework really difficult or struggled to understand the instructions (I found them unclear and chatgpt could explain the instructions in more detail). I generally avoid using it to get answers straight up. It's also useful to ensure I didn't forget any major step/area of thinking, so I usually check with it at the end how it would solve the problem. 
Also, as a person with very little coding background, I often found coding assignments difficult, I used chatgpt to transform my pseudocode into python code. Or to ensure I am not missing comments/find typos. Or (especially important) to write latex code (tables take a really long time to do by hand).
column45:

It would be helpful though if the tutors/lecturers told us when something is so important that we should do some background reading (a problem is when we don't know what we don't know)

column26:
Generative AI offers a lot of mundane utility; if you read the Zvi Mowshowitz newsletter 'Dont Worry About the Vase', he details a lot of those uses. I personally find it very helpful for solving configuration issues in Linux and translating code between languages. Current performance on world knowledge can be hit-or-miss, but since you can ask multiple good free models the same question, you can get a 'consensus opinion' that outperforms any model individually. 

For example, recently I wanted to know what the heaviest rail bridge in the world was. This question is practically impossible to Google (try it!) as you mostly get results relating to the biggest / highest rail bridges rather than lists by tonnage. So I asked GPT-3.5, Gemini, and Mixtral-7B on groq and got a bunch of useful lists of large bridges. They didn't all agree with each other, but they gave me a great place to start looking.
column37: They can be great partners for talking through ideas, but they also get a lot of specific questions wrong. So the best way to use them is not to answer things for you, but to point you in the right direction so you know which keywords to search wikipedia for.

column26: I have not really used generative AI tools at all but I keep up with people who do research into them and their use in maths and writing applications, and I have seen them used by my classmates on a few occasions.
column37: I find the development of AI tools quite interesting and am not opposed to them on principle, and have seen people use ChatGPT to generate quick ideas for things like fun games and slogans with some success. However, I would be extremely hesitant to use them for any kind of serious research until the way they worked changed to ensure that what they generated was actually accurate - although I hear that they usually are, I would not trust them as long as there is a chance that the information given might be false. This is especially true for maths where the small details of a proof and how they come together to create the big picture are so important - I have seen many AI generated proofs that "look" like proofs but don't hold up under close inspection. Similarly, I have seen AI generated code that was extremely strange, messy and inefficient, and took 6 lines to do something an experienced human could do in only 1 or 2. I think this comes from the inability to see the big picture and plan out the structure of something before writing it, although I have heard there are more specialised tools that are better for maths and programming applications.
column45: I think AI will be very important in the future, bad news for me because I don't have any skills with it and am reluctant to use it because of my suspicions. I hope that people will be sensible with it and it won't cause any problems but I don't think that's true as I have already seen AI-generated articles clogging up search results and AI being misused in settings where the consequences of its mistakes have been pretty serious. However, I do think it has the potential to save people a lot of time on simple jobs and help in a lot of areas. It can even be better than humans at spotting certain data patterns, just as long as a human checks the results before doing anything serious with them.

column26: "I prefer traditional search engines over Generative AI tools for information." - This is complicated as many articles on the internet are AI-generated making it harder and harder to find reliable info, it also depends on the type of information I am looking for, technical information related to my studies can usually be found in textbooks/papers and is well-presented but, for example, substitutes for cooking ingredients in a recipe are easier to get from Generative AI.
column37:
"Generative AI tools provide little assistance in numerical and quantitative subjects." - no experience
"Generative AI tools effectively overcome language barriers in education." - Generative AI tends to have an English language bias, unsure how this impacts the claim.
"Using Generative AI for homework does not diminish the educational value." - it depends on its usage, within the context of computer programming Generative AI can improve productivity and effectively reduce the amount of boilerplate code which may empower the student to spend their time more efficiently on their understanding rather than rote work but it can also fill gaps in a students understanding, skipping the learning process, and resulting in worse educational outcomes.
column45:
"The use of Generative AI tools in academic settings should be allowed." - 1) Resources used in the academic process must be appropriately cited, e.g. using seaborn for data visualisation must be cited, this also holds for intermediate cases, i.e. a calculation handled in the background was performed using code written by another author, even if not directly shown in a paper, must be cited. Given this Generative AI resources must be cited, however tools like ChatGPT, due to their backbox nature, cannot be appropriately cited and hence their use in certain contexts can be seen as a form of academic misconduct. 2) Due to the technical nature of academic work transparency, honesty, and trustworthiness are important for fellow academics, and knowledge that Generative AI was used in the process can undermine that trust especially while the guidelines on academic integrity in relation to Generative AI are not common knowledge, note that this point also has an analogue w.r.t the public as the use of Generative AI in a work can lead to negative publicity. 3) given the above the use of Generative AI in an academic context is limited however it is important to not limit academic freedom, restrictions on Generative AI tools would naturally hamper the development and research of such systems and as such should not be taken. 4) In conclusion the use of Generative AI tools should be allowed but it is of great importance to promote discourse about the ethics of their use and their appropriate place in academic settings such that Academic Integrity is maintained.
"Proficiency in Generative AI tools will be crucial for competitiveness in future job markets."/"AI will dramatically influence work, society, and daily life in the next 5 years." - it is unclear to me if AI will have a major impact, given its potential to cause harm and job displacement such tools may end up heavily restricted in commercial contexts but based on the current trajectory, if such tools end up having prominence the result will be a net negative for society as a whole.
